https://www.richardscotford.com/single-post/2017/09/08/HK-Student-Unions-should-encourage-Mainland-students-to-engage-in-the-Independence-debate

HK Student Unions should encourage Mainland students to engage in the Independence debate.

Richard Scotford


I have a Master's Degree from CUHK in Chinese Studies. During my studies, I would say as many as 50% of the students on my course were from the Mainland. On a degree that focused on all things to do with China; it's not long before your wander into topics that have the potential to be highly controversial. However, what was striking from the Mainland students was their reluctance to have any strong public opinions on any topic, no matter how controversial. One of the modules I chose on my Master's Degree was, U.S and Taiwan Relations, taught by Frank Ching, which I scored an A+ in by the way. Throughout that entire semester, I never had one debate with Mainland students about Taiwan. They just weren't there to express their opinions.

This deafening silence from the enormous, latent army of Mainland students in Hong Kong is no accident. It is by design. If the powers that be wanted all these students to rally in Central against Hong Kong Independence they would turn out in force. But that's not how the CCP wants it. So, instead, when there are anti-democracy or anti-HK Independence marches, we see the same crusty faces of washed up blue ribbons, who barely have any education, turning up.

Mainland students are NOT in Hong Kong to express political opinions and form political groups, no matter how nationalistic they may be.

Why is this?

The simple answer is that the skills that could be needed to set up an anti-HK Independence movement could one day be used to create an anti-CCP movement. Acquiring such political skills has to be avoided, at all costs!

There is a precedent for this
Back-in-the-day, Facebook was allowed across China. The reason why it was banned was the Lhasa and Xinjiang Riots. In the aftermath of the sudden riots, the authorities quickly realized the power of Facebook. They weren't worried about Free Tibet messages which were flooding Facebook. What worried them was the rapid, nationalistic response from Chinese citizens supporting the colonization of Tibet. This movement was centered around a Facebook group called - Tibet WAS and ALWAYS will be part of CHINA! Interestingly, this groups was set up by a person in Taiwan.


I spent many hours in this group, and it was a 24hr blood bath of hardcore Free Tibeters and Han nationalists, from all over the world, locking horns.
The CCP quickly saw that Facebook had the potential to be a political nuclear bomb. This was way before the Arab Spring. They realized that groups of keyboard warriors were quickly becoming political heavy weights, with the potential to influence government policy through massive waves of popular, cyber opinion. It didn't matter that this group consisted of rabid Han nationalists and staunch supporters of the CCP. Those holding power, were not about to share it with a new group of twenty-somethings with uncontrollable cyber clout.
So, Facebook was shut down. Not to curb the foreign interference but as a control on the very people who supported the CCP the most.

Uncontrolled nationalism by overseas students is a complete no-no and a danger to The Party.

For this reason, I believe that the Student Unions of all Hong Kong Universities should step up the pressure to present Hong Kong Independence as a freedom of speech issue that challenges and is safe guarded by the Basic Law.
After all, Article 1 of the Basic Law is not a pervasive law that every citizen can be held to legally. Everyone is free to imagine and discuss what Hong Kong could look like outside of being an inalienable part of China. This freedom of thought is protected by the Basic Law.

The Hong Kong Independence debate is ultimately not about, whether Hong Kong can practically set itself up in a vacuum, free from China's grip. The essential part of the debate is; is there a future for Hong Kong and China outside of the CCP leadership? What shape would Hong Kong take, if the CCP were to be removed from power? Or if China were to have huge internal change within the country?

The CCP's reign is a drop in the ocean in comparison to China's long and tumultuous history and there will come a time when it ends. This is what the Hong Kong Independence debate is about. When this time comes, how should Hong Kong, an international, outward facing city present itself?
This is why the debate is so important and should be staunchly protected by everyone who respects free speech. It's not about creating a separatist movement to violently secede from the Mainland. But instead, it's about discussing all possibilities of Hong Kong's future.

Therefore, the Students Unions should embrace the politicization of Mainland students over this topic. Try and bring them into the debate about what China or Hong Kong would look like outside of CCP rule. Release them from their Stockholm Syndrome, created by the oppressive Mainland education system. Encourage them to express their opinions, form groups and engage in political debates with views they've never heard before.

Universities are about expanding the mind to the possibilities of what if...

Right now in Hong Kong, no topic is more controversial than Independence, and as the debate becomes wider, more and more Mainlanders will see that there is not only a better future for HK outside of the grip of CCP, there is also a better future for China.

Ah, but what am I talking about, the CCP will order the students to stand down and return to their studies before any real political debate is achieved. So really, the HK Students Union has nothing to lose.
